choices.text: Surface tension of alveoli is less than normal
A greater than normal pressure difference between the inside and outside of the lungs is required for lung inflation
Large alveoli collapse more easily than small alveoli
Pressures due to surface tension in large and small alveoli are equal

questions.text: All except the following are false in a premature infant without pulmonary surfactant-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

According to the law of Laplace, the DISTENDING pressure required to prevent collapse of an alveolus (P) is directly proportional to surface tension (T) and inversely proportional to alveolar radius (r), as expressed by P = 2T/r. Therefore, a greater pressure difference is required to inflate alveoli to overcome surface forces. Lack of surfactant will increase surface tension. Small alveoli collapse more easily than large alveoli. Lack of surfactant makes pressures different in large and small alveoli.

choices.text: Dorsal horn of the spinal cord
Ventral horn of the spinal cord

questions.text: Enkephalinergic interneurons that are most likely to inhibit afferent pain signals are most likely to be found in which of the following regions of the central nervous system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Dorsal horn of the spinal cord
Enkephalinergic interneurons in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord cause a pre-synaptic and post-synaptic inhibition of the pain pathway decreasing pain transmission

choices.text: The maximum and minimum left ventricular pressures are virtually the same as systolic and diastolic pressures measured in a peripheral artery
Left ventricular pressure rises continuously during filling
> 90% of the end-diastolic volume is ejected
The mitral valve is open longer than is the aortic valve

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Diastole, when the mitral valve is open, lasts longer than systole, when the aortic valve is open. Once the aortic valve closes, left ventricular pressure falls well below arterial pressure. When the mitral valve opens, the ventricle is still relaxing, and pressure continues to fall during the initial phase of filling. Typically 30% to 50% of the end-diastolic volume remains at the end of systole

questions.text: What is the calculated vascular resistance to blood flow through the kidneys from the following data? Systolic arterial pressure = 130 mm Hg, diastolic arterial pressure = 70 mm Hg, mean renal venous pressure = 10 mm Hg, renal blood flow = 800 mL/min, renal arterial compliance = 4 mL/mm Hg.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Resistance is the pressure difference driving flow (MAP minus mean venous pressure) divided by flow. MAP equals diastolic pressure plus one-third of pulse pressure, which is 70 + (130 –70)/3 = 90 mm Hg. Thus, the pressure difference is 90 – 10 = 80 mm Hg and resistance is 80 mm Hg /800 mL/min = 0.1 mm Hg/mL/min

choices.text: Excites D2 receptors in the direct pathway and inhibits D1 receptors in the indirect pathway
Inhibits D1 receptors in both direct and indirect pathways
Excites D1 receptors in the direct pathway and inhibits D2 receptors in the indirect pathway
Inhibits D2 receptors in the direct pathway and excites D1 receptors in the indirect pathway

questions.text: 80-year-old man presents with resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity. His condition improves temporarily with administration of a dopamine precursor.  Dopaminergic input from the substantia nigra pars compacta normally facilitates movement via its effect on the direct and indirect pathways. Which of the following best describes the effect of dopamine on striatal neurons in these two pathways?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Excites D1 receptors in the direct pathway and inhibits D2 receptors in the indirect pathway.  The basal ganglia modulate movement through two main pathways:

Direct pathway (movement facilitation):

• Cortex → (+) Striatum (D1) → (–) GPi/SNr → (–) Thalamus → (+) Motor cortex

• Dopamine excites D1 receptors, enhancing the inhibition of GPi → disinhibition of thalamus → increased movement.
Indirect pathway (movement inhibition):

• Cortex → (+) Striatum (D2) → (–) GPe → (–) STN → (+) GPi → (–) Thalamus → ↓ movement

• Dopamine inhibits D2 receptors, reducing indirect pathway activity → less inhibition of thalamus → increased movement.
So overall, dopamine promotes movement by:

• Exciting the direct pathway (via D1)

• Inhibiting the indirect pathway (via D2)

questions.text: The following laboratory values were obtained in a 58-year-old man: Urine flow rate = 3 ml/min. Serum creatinine = 3 mg/100 ml Urine creatinine = 50 mg/100 ml Plasma potassium = 4.0 mmol/l Urine potassium = 30 mmol/l What is his approximate GFR, assuming that he collected all of his urine in the 24-hour period?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

GFR is approximately equal to creatinine clearance, which is calculated as the urine creatinine concentration (50 mg/100 ml) × urine flow rate (3 ml/min)/plasma creatinine concentration (3 mg/100 ml), which is equal to 50 ml/min.

choices.text: Is prolonged if the stimulus is strong
Is an example of a flexor reflex
Is accompanied by the same response on both sides of the body

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the withdrawal reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

The flexor withdrawal reflex occurs in response to a nociceptive stimulus. If the stimulus is strong enough it is accompanied by the crossed extensor response on the opposite side

choices.text: High degree of electrical coupling between cells
Elevation of intracellular [Ca2+] for muscle contraction
Spontaneous depolarization of the membrane potential

questions.text: Which characteristic or component is shared by skeletal muscle and smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

An elevation of intracellular [Ca2+] is common to the mechanism of excitation–contraction coupling in skeletal and smooth muscle. In skeletal muscle, Ca2+ binds to troponin C, initiating the cross-bridge cycle. In smooth muscle, Ca2+ binds to calmodulin. The Ca2+–calmodulin complex activates myosin light chain kinase, which phosphorylates myosin so that shortening can occur. The striated appearance of the sarcomeres and the presence of troponin are characteristic of skeletal, not smooth, muscle. Spontaneous depolarizations and gap junctions are characteristics of unitary smooth
muscle

questions.text:
A medical student is studying the fluid exchange in skeletal muscle capillaries in a laboratory animal. He determines that fluid is being filtered out of the capillaries with a net filtration pressure of 10mmHg. He obtains the following values –

Capillary hydrostatic pressure is 45mmHg

Capillary oncotic pressure is 25 mmHg

Interstitial oncotic pressure is 10mmHg

Which of the following is the interstitial hydrostatic pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Starling forces govern the rate of filtration across capillaries. It depends on four pressures – capillary hydrostatic pressure, capillary oncotic pressure, interstitial hydrostatic pressure and interstitial oncotic pressure. So, NFP= PCap + πIF – PIF – πcap .  From the above data, 
10= 45+ 10 – 25 + πIF   = 30 + πIF , hence πIF= 20mmHg.

choices.text: Hypernatremia, increased plasma osmolality & decreased ICF volume
Hyponatremia, decreased plasma osmolality & increased ECF volume
Hypernatremia, decreased urine osmolality & increased ECF volume
Hyponatremia, increased plasma osmolality & decreased ECF volume

questions.text: A patient with SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion) will most likely show which of the following laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Hyponatremia, decreased plasma osmolality and increased ECF volume. 
Excess ADH causes water retention → dilutional hyponatremia and reduced ECF (plasma osmolality). Water will shift from ECF to ICF resulting in increased ICF volume till osmolarity is same. 
Urine is inappropriately concentrated.
• A: Opposite findings.
• C: ADH increases urine concentration, not decreases it.
• D: Plasma osmolality decreases, not increases.

questions.text: In the figure shown below, the shift from curve A to curve B could be caused by-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Because fetal hemoglobin (HbF) has a greater affinity for O2 than does adult hemoglobin, the O2–hemoglobin dissociation curve would shift to the left. Carbon monoxide poisoning would cause a shift to the left, but would also cause a decrease in total O2-carrying capacity (decreased percent saturation) because CO occupies O2-binding sites. Decreased pH, increased temperature, and increased 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (DPG) all would shift the curve to the right

questions.text: A new drug is developed that blocks the transporter for H+ secretion in gastric parietal cells. Which of the following transport processes is being inhibited?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

H+ secretion by gastric parietal cells occurs by H+–K+ adenosine triphosphatase (ATPase), a primary active transporter.

questions.text: Stimulation of which of the following would most likely result in rapid, shallow breathing in response to pulmonary congestion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Juxtacapillary (J) receptors
J receptors, located in alveolar walls near capillaries, respond to pulmonary congestion or edema, leading to rapid, shallow breathing. This is commonly seen in left-sided heart failure

questions.text: A 34 old male rapidly ascends to high altitude, starts hyperventilating and develops respiratory alkalosis. After several days, his tissues acclimatize and receive more oxygen despite alkalosis. Which of the following is the primary mechanism at tissue level for improved oxygen delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Increase in 2,3 DPG enhances oxygen delivery to tissues. This causes rights shift of oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve

questions.text: An 80-year-old man is brought to the Emergency with complaints of nausea, vomiting, muscle cramps, and generalized weakness. Laboratory analysis reveals moderate hyperkalemia. Elevations of extracellular potassium ion concentration will have which of the following effects on the nerve membranes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

RMP becomes less negative or more positive 
In hyperkalemia, the potassium gradient between the inside and outside the cell decreases. This reduces the rate of potassium efflux resulting in more positive ions inside the cell. This causes the RMP to become less negative or the cell depolarizes
